text: Syntheses, Crystal Structures and Characterization of Two Coordination Polymers Based on Mixed Ligands

WANG Yu-Fang(l (王玉芳);HE Chao-Jun(2 (何朝军) (1) College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, and Henan Key Laboratory of Function-oriented Porous Materials, Luoyang Normal University, Luoyang 471934,China;(2 School ofFood and Drug, Luoyang Normal University, Luoyang,Henan 471934,China

ABSTRACT Twonewcoordinationpolymers， namely， $\{ \mathrm { [ C d _ { 1 . 5 } ( b c ) _ { 2 } ( H L ) ] . H _ { 2 } O } \} _ { 2 n }$ (1)and $\mathrm { \Delta [ M n ( i p ) ( H _ { 2 } L ) ( H _ { 2 } O ) ] _ { n } } ( 2 )$ $\mathrm { \mathrm { ~ H } } _ { 2 } \mathrm { L } = 3$ (1H-pyrazol-4-yl)-5-(pyridin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazole, Hbc $\mathbf { \tau } = \mathbf { \tau }$ benzoic acid, Hip $\mathbf { \Sigma } = \mathbf { \Sigma }$ isophthalic acid） were constructed by solvothermal reaction.The compounds were characterized by elemental analysis， FT-IR spectroscopy，and single-crystal $\mathrm { \Delta } X$ -ray diffraction. Compound 1 displaysa two-dimensional plane structure consisting of $\mathrm { [ C d _ { 3 } ( b c ) _ { 2 } ( H L ) ] }$ subunits. Compound 2 possessesa one-dimensional chain structure and is further extended into a 3-D supramolecular architecture via hydrogen bonds.Moreover, photoluminescence studies showed compound 1 exhibits luminescent emisions with emission maximaat $3 7 5 \mathrm { ~ \ n m }$ .Magnetic susceptibility measurements of 2 indicate that domain antiferromagnetic interactions exist between $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ ions. In addition, thermogravimetric properties of 1 and 2 were also measured.
Keywords: cadmium(II); manganese(II); crystal structure; luminescence; magnetic property DOI:10.14102/j.cnki.0254-5861.2011-1773
1 INTRODUCTION

The design and synthesis of new coordination polymers are nowadays a challenging research topic that attracts increasing interest due to the creation of various intriguing architectures and their potential applications[l-7]of such metal-organic materials. As we all know,the selection of organic ligands is very important in the construction of coordination polymers.Recently,N-donor ligands have been widely employed in the construction of coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks with intriguing structure.To modulate the structure，different polycarboxylate ligandscan be used as auxiliary ligands to direct the self-assembly. Although these appealing topology and interesting properties of metal coordination frameworks that have been synthesized by various N-donor ligands and aromatic carboxylic acid have so far been explored to a great extent in the area ofcrystal enginering to datel8-11],the synthesis of compositionally and structurally designed MOFs and their composites remains a significant challenge nowadays owing to the difficulty in fine-tunningthephasedistributionsandarchitecturesofthefinalproducts.Weselected 3-(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)-5-(pyridin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazole as ligand and benzoicand isophthalicacidsasauxiliary ligands in this paper. Herein we synthesized two new coordination polymers, $\{ \mathrm  [ C d _ { 1 . 5 } ( b c ) _ { 2 } ( H L ) ] { \cdot } H _ { 2 } O \} _ { 2 n } ( \mathbf { 1 } )$ and $\mathrm { \Delta [ M n ( i p ) ( H _ { 2 } L ) ( H _ { 2 } O ) ] _ { n } }$ (2).Thosestructureinducingphysicalproperties，likethermalstability, photoluminescence, magnetic properties and so forth is also described and discussed.
2 EXPERIMENTAL
2. 1 Materials andcharacterization

All reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen atoms were carried out on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. The IR spectrum was recorded $( 4 0 0 \sim 4 0 0 0 ~ \mathrm { c m } ^ { - 1 }$ region） on a SHIMADZU IR Afinity-1S Spectrometer. All fluorescence measurementswere carriedout on an F-7Ooo Fluorescence Spectrophometer $2 2 0  { \sim } 2 4 0  { \mathrm { V } ) }$ ： Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA） were carried out in nitrogen at a heating rate of $1 0 \ \mathrm { ^ { \circ } C \cdot m i n ^ { - 1 } }$ using a TG/DTA 63O0 integration thermal analyzer. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corctions were made with Pascal's constants for all constituent atoms.
2.2Preparation of $\{ [ \mathbf { C d _ { 1 . 5 } ( b c ) _ { 2 } ( H L ) } ] { \cdot } \mathbf { H } _ { 2 } \mathbf { O } \} _ { 2 \mathrm { n } } ( \mathbf { 1 } )$

A mixture of $\mathrm { C d } ( \mathrm { N O } _ { 3 } ) _ { 2 } { \cdot } 4 \mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O }$ (92.5 mg, 0.30 mmol), $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { L }$ (21.2 mg, 0.10 mmol),Hbc (36.6 mg,0.30 mmol) and KOH (11.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O }$ ,added in a $1 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ small glass bottle after stirring and then sealed in a $2 5 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave at $1 3 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 7 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ ，followed by slowly cooling to room temperature at a rate of $5 ~ { } ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } { \cdot } \mathrm { h } ^ { - 1 }$ . Light yellow block-shaped crystals were obtained in $54 \%$ yield,washed with water and air-dried. IR $( \mathrm { c m ^ { - 1 } } ;$ ): 3433(w), 3180(w), 2976(w), 2363(m), 2336(m), 1581(m), 1536(m),1526(m),1383(m),1300(m),1150(m),1069(m),1025(m),952(m),848(m),765(m),710(m),670(m),
2.3Preparation of $[ \mathbf { M n } ( \mathbf { i p } ) ( \mathbf { H } _ { 2 } \mathbf { L } ) ( \mathbf { H } _ { 2 } \mathbf { O } ) ] _ { \mathbf { n } } ( 2 )$

The preparation of 2 was similar to that of 1 except that $\mathrm { M n S O } _ { 4 } { \cdot } 4 \mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O }$ and Hbc were used instead of $\mathrm { C d } ( \mathrm { N O } _ { 3 } ) _ { 2 } { \cdot } 4 \mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O }$ and H2ip. Light-brown crystals of 2 were obtained in $50 \%$ yield. IR $( \mathrm { c m ^ { - 1 } } )$ ): 3429 (w), 3056 (w),2465(m),2320(m),1617 (m),1595 (m),1558 (m),1476 (m),1401 (m),1308 (m),1196 (m),1057 (m),784 (m), 716 (m). Anal. Calcd. $( \% )$ )for C18H14MnN6O5: C, 48.12; H, 3.14; N,18.71. Found $( \% )$ : C, 48.45; H, 3.12; N, 18.58.
2. 4Crystal structure determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of compounds 1 and 2 were collected with a Rigaku Oxford SuperNova diffractometer with a MoKα radiation $( \lambda = 0 . 7 1 0 7 3 \mathrm { ~ \AA ~ }$ ). Intensities were collected and reduced on the program CrysAlisPro (Rigaku Oxford, Version 1.171.39.3a),and a multi-scan absorption correction was applied. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97[12] and refined on $F ^ { 2 }$ by full-matrix least-squares with SHELXL-97[131. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and all hydrogen atoms were asigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restrains.The details of crystal parameters are summarized in Table 1,and the selected bond lengths are listed in Table 2.
3 RESULTSANDDISCUSSION
3.1 Structure description
3.1.1Crystal structure of $\{ { \bf [ C d _ { 1 . 5 } ( b c ) _ { 2 } ( H L ) ] \cdot H _ { 2 } O } \} _ { 2 n } ( 1$ ）

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group $P 2 _ { 1 } / n$ and exhibits a 2D layered framework,and its asymmetric unit contains one and a half Cd atoms, one $\mathrm { H L } ^ { - }$ ligand, two $ { \mathbf { b } }  { \mathrm { c } } ^ { - }$ ligands and one uncoordinated water molecule.As shown in Fig.1, the two $\operatorname { C d } ( \operatorname { I I } )$ ions in1 are both six-coordinated,in which the $\operatorname { C d } ( 1 )$ ion with 1/2 occupation is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N(4),N(4)#1) of two different $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { L }$ ligands and four oxygen atoms (O(2), O(2)#1,O(3),O(3)#1) from four different Hbc ligands. The $\operatorname { C d } ( 1 )$ is located in an inversion center. While Cd(2) is coordinated by three nitrogen atoms (N(1), N(3), N(6)#2) of two different $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { L }$ ligands and three oxygen atoms(O(1)，O(3） and O(4)） from two different $ { \mathbf { b } }  { \mathrm { c } } ^ { - }$ ligands.Besides,the two adjacent Cd(II) atoms are bridged by O(1) and O(2) atoms of carboxylate group from one bc- ligand and a bifurcated O(3）atom of carboxylate group from another $ { \mathbf { b } }  { \mathbf { c } } ^ { - }$ ligand,and another O(4) atom of carboxylate group from this bc- ligand is linked to Cd(2) atom. At the same time, the two adjacent $\operatorname { C d } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ ions are bridged by N(3) and N(4) atoms of triazole from $\mathrm { H L ^ { - } }$ ligand, and $\mathbf { N } ( 1 )$ atom of pyridine from this $\mathrm { H L ^ { - } }$ ligand is linked to Cd(2)ion.The Cd-Odistances fallintherange of $2 . 1 8 9 2 ( 1 9 ) { \sim } 2 . 5 8 9 0 ( 1 9 ) \mathring \mathrm { A }$ , and the Cd-N distances vary from 2.261(2) to 2.403(2)A. These bond angles and bond distances all fallin the normal ranges[14l. In compound 1, two pairs of oppositely arranged bc" anions and one pair of oppositely arranged $\mathrm { H L ^ { - } }$ anions bind three Cd(II) ions (two Cd(2） and one $\operatorname { C d } ( 1 ) \quad$ ）to form the $\mathrm { \Gamma } [ \mathrm { C d } _ { 3 } ( \mathrm { b c } ) _ { 2 } ( \mathrm { H L } ) ]$ subunit,with the $\mathrm { C d } ( 1 ) { \cdots } \mathrm { C d } ( 2 )$ separation to be $3 . 8 0 6 \mathring { \mathrm { A } }$ . Then the trinuclear subunits are linked to form an infinite two-dimensional network by an $\mathrm { H L ^ { - } }$ ligand bridging mode (Fig. 2).

In addition, in the crystal packing,there are hydrogen bonding interactions among uncoordinated water molecules and nitrogen atoms of $\mathrm { H L ^ { - } }$ ligands and oxygen atoms of $ { \mathbf { b } }  { \mathbf { c } } ^ { - }$ ligands $( \mathrm { N } ( 5 ) { \mathrm { - H } } ( 5 ) { \cdots } \mathrm { O } ( 5 ) \# 1$ （204号 (H….O/N.….O distance $= ~ 1 . 9 6 / 2 . 7 4 9 ( 3 ) ~ i$ $\mathring \mathbf { A }$ angle $= 1 5 2 . 3 ^ { \circ } .$ ); O(5)-H(5A)N(2)#2 (H··N/O.N distance $\mathbf { \tau } = \mathbf { \tau }$ 1.94/2.789(3) A, angle $= 1 7 1 . 9 ^ { \circ } .$ ); O(5)-H(5B)..O(4) (H.O/O...O distance $= 1 . 9 4 / 2 . 7 3 8 ( 3 ) \mathring { \mathrm { A } }$ , angle $= 1 5 7 . 2 )$ ） The 2D architecture of 1 is also reinforced by extensive hydrogen bonding interactions.
3. 1. 2 Crystal structure of $[ \mathbf { M n } ( \mathbf { i p } ) ( \mathbf { H } _ { 2 } \mathbf { L } ) ( \mathbf { H } _ { 2 } \mathbf { O } ) ] _ { \mathbf { n } } ( 2 )$

X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that 2 crystalizes in monoclinic system, space group $P 2 _ { 1 } / n$ and exhibits a 1D framework. As shown in Fig. 3, the asymmetric unit contains one $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ ion, one $_ \mathrm { H _ { 2 } L }$ ligand and one $\mathrm { i p } ^ { 2 - }$ ligand. The $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ center is five-coordinated to two nitrogen atoms (N(2) and N(3)) from the same $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { L }$ ligand, three oxygen atoms (O(1), ${ \mathrm { O } } ( 4 ) ^ { \# 1 } ,$ from two different H2ip ligands and one oxygen atom (O(5)) from one coordinated water molecule. The Mn-N distances are 2.223(2) and 2.260(2) $\mathring \mathbf { A }$ , respectively. And the Mn-O lengths fall in the range of $2 . 1 6 5 3 ( 1 8 ) { \sim } 2 . 2 1 7 5 ( 1 8 ) \mathring { \mathrm { A } }$ ，which fall in the normal range of those observed in manganese complexes[15]. And there are weak coordinated bonds $( \mathrm { M n } ( 1 ) { \cdots } \mathrm { O } ( 2 ) = 2 . 6 6 5$ and $\mathrm { M n } ( 1 ) { \cdots } 0 ( 3 ) = 2 . 5 5 9 \mathrm { ~ \AA ~ } ;$ ） in 2, resulting in two carboxylate groups of $\mathrm { i p } ^ { 2 - }$ ligand nearly coplanar. The $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { L }$ ligand adopts the chelating mode to connect one $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ atom through one imidazole $\mathbf { N }$ atom and one pyridine N atom. At the same time, two carboxyl groups of $\mathrm { i p } ^ { 2 - }$ ligand in compound 2 are completely deprotonated and exhibit coordination mode $\mathsf { { H } } _ { 2 } \mathsf { - } \mathsf { \Pi } \mathsf { \Pi } ^ { 1 } \mathsf { { : } } \mathsf { { \boldsymbol { \eta } } } ^ { 1 }$ to link two $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ ions, finally forming a one-dimensional chain with the Mn.-Mn distances of $1 0 . 1 6 0 \mathring { \mathrm { A } }$ =

In the crystal packing,there are H-bonding interactions among pyridine $\mathbf { N }$ atom,imidazole $\mathbf { N }$ atom, coordinated water molecule and carboxyl groups of $\mathrm { i p } ^ { 2 - }$ ligand: $( \mathrm { N } ( 5 ) \mathrm { - } \mathrm { H } ( 5 ) \mathrm { - } \mathrm { \cdot } \mathrm { O } ( 2 )$ (H….O/N..O distance $\mathbf { \tau } = \mathbf { \tau }$ $1 . 9 9 5 / 2 . 8 3 1 \mathrm { ~ \AA ~ }$ ,angle $= 1 6 3 . 6 ^ { \circ } )$ ; O(5)-H(5A)….O(1) (H··N/OO distance $= 1 . 8 6 5 / 2 . 7 4 7 \mathrm { ~ \AA ~ }$ , angle $= 1 5 3 . 8 ^ { \circ } )$ ：

O(5)-H(5B)…O(4) (H··N/O….O distance $= 1 . 9 3 3 / 2 . 7 5 6 \mathrm { ~ \AA ~ }$ ，angle $= 1 6 2 . 5 )$ ； N(7)-H(7)·O(3) (H··N/N…O distance $= 2 . 2 6 8 / 2 . 9 1 8 \mathrm { ~ \AA ~ }$ ， angle $= 1 3 2 . 5 ^ { \circ } )$ ). In addition, $\pi ^ { \cdot \cdot \cdot \pi }$ piling interactions exist between the nearest neighboring benzene rings which parallel each other with the interplane distances of $4 . 0 7 0 \mathring \mathrm { A }$ .These hydrogen bonds and $\pi ^ { \cdot \cdot \cdot \pi }$ stacking interactions lead to the formation of a 3-D supramolecular network (Fig. 4),in which the $\mathbf { M n } { \cdots } \mathbf { M n }$ separation is $4 . 8 0 0 \mathring { \mathrm { A } }$
3.2Luminescence spectra of compound 1

As shown in Fig. 5, the complexes with $d ^ { 1 0 }$ metal centers have been investigated for fluorescent properties and for potential applications as fluorescence emitting materials.It should be noted that $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { L }$ ligand displays fluorescence in the solid state at room temperature,while compound 1 exhibits different fluorescence. The ligand maximum appears at an excitation wavelength $\lambda _ { \mathrm { e x } } = 3 2 5 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ ，with a maximum emission peak at $\lambda _ { \mathrm { e m } } =$ $3 8 0 \mathrm { n m }$ .In 1, there is an excitation maximum at $2 7 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ with a maximum emission peak at $3 7 5 ~ \mathrm { { n m } }$ . It can be seen clearly that compared with the ligand $\mathrm { H _ { 2 } L }$ ,the emission peak of compound1 has slight blue shift by 380 to $3 7 5 \ \mathrm { n m }$ . The phenomena should be best ascribed to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer according to literatures[16-18].
3.3Magnetic properties of compound 2

For 2,the solid-state magnetic susceptibility was measured on a polycrystalline sample at 2Ooo Oe over the temperature range of $2 \sim 3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$ .A plot of the $\chi _ { \mathrm { M } } \mathrm { T }$ vs. T susceptibility data for 2 is shown in Fig. 6. The value of $\chi _ { \mathrm { M } } \mathrm { T }$ at $3 0 0 \mathrm { K }$ is 8.80 emu mol-1 K, which is slightly higher than the expected spin-only value for two $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ ions $( 8 . 7 5 \mathrm { \ e m u \ m o l ^ { - 1 } \ K } )$ . As the temperature is lowered, the $\chi _ { \mathrm { M } } \mathrm { T }$ value decreases slowly to $8 . 7 5 \mathrm { \ e m u }$ （204号 $\mathrm { m o l ^ { - 1 } K }$ a $2 \mathrm { K }$ . This indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions within the sample.

The crystal packing of 2,which is driven by hydrogen-bonding，reveals intermolecular $\mathbf { M n } { \cdots } \mathbf { M n }$ separation distance of $4 . 8 0 0 \mathrm { ~ \AA ~ }$ ， regarding the intrachain $\mathbf { M n } { \cdots } \mathbf { M n }$ separation distance of $1 0 . 1 6 0 \mathrm { ~ \AA ~ }$ . And the Mn-Mn dinuclear fragment formed by the two Mn-COO.HO(H)-Mn paths is characterized by the shortest metal-metal separation distance $( 4 . 8 0 0 \mathring { \mathbf { A } } )$ . Moreover, the magnetic exchange between transition metal centers through hydrogen-bonding interactions involving coordinated water molecules is wel-exemplified in the literature[19,20l.The Heisenberg spin Hamiltonian model $( \hat { H } = - J S _ { 1 } S _ { 2 }$ $\mathbf { S } _ { 1 } = \mathbf { S } _ { 2 } = 5 / 2 ) ^ { [ 2 1 , }$ 221 for the isotropic magnetic exchange interaction in the dinuclear $\mathbf { M n } ( 2 )$ unit is given in Eq. (1).
A=55exp[30J/KT] + 30exp[20J/KT] $^ +$ 14exp[12J/KT] $^ +$ 5exp[6J/KT] $^ +$ exp[2J/KT]

A good fit was achieved with the fitting parameters as follows: $J = - 0 . 2 3 \ \mathrm { c m } ^ { - 1 }$ ， $g = 2 . 0 0 4$ and the agreement factor $\mathrm { ~ R ~ } = \sum [ ( \chi _ { \mathrm { M } } ) _ { \mathrm { o b s } } - ( \chi _ { \mathrm { M } } ) _ { \mathrm { c a l c } } ] ^ { 2 } / \sum ( \chi _ { \mathrm { M } } ) _ { \mathrm { o b s } } ^ { 2 }$ is $1 . 0 8 \times 1 0 ^ { - 5 }$ . The analysis confirms weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ atoms bridged by hydrogen-bonding. The hydrogen interactions provide an effective pathway for the magnetic exchange interaction between $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ atoms. The small $J$ value observed may be explained by the fact that the magnetic orbitals are unfavorably oriented to interact.
3.4Thermogravimetric analyses of compounds 1 and 2

In order to further characterize compounds 1 and 2,their thermal analyses were performed under ${ \bf N } _ { 2 }$ atmosphere at a heating rate of $1 0 ~ \mathrm { { ^ circ C / m i n } }$ in the temperature range of $3 0 { \sim } 8 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ 、As shown in Fig. 7, the TGA curves of 1 and 2 indicated that the samples undergo two main weight loss steps and the coordinated water molecules were lost in the ranges of $1 4 0 \sim 1 9 0$ and $1 6 0 { \sim } 2 4 0 \ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for 1 and 2, respectively. The weight loss of $2 . 9 2 \%$ and $4 . 1 8 \%$ is consistent with the calculated values $2 . 8 1 \%$ and $4 . 0 1 \%$ ). Then the framework began to decompose with continuous weight loss above 26O and $3 4 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for 1 and 2,respectively. The final residues of $2 9 . 6 3 \%$ (calcd. $3 0 . 0 6 \%$ for 1 and $1 5 . 5 8 \%$ (calcd. $1 5 . 7 8 \%$ ) for 2 may be the CdO and MnO powder, respectively. The results suggest that the backbone of 2 is more thermally robust than 1,and can resist decomposition at temperature up to $3 4 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$
3.5 XRD analyses

In order to check whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out for 1 and 2 at room temperature. As shown in Fig. 8, the peak positions of the simulated and experimental PXRD pattrns are in agreement with each other, demonstrating that the bulk synthesized materials and the measured single crystals are the same.

text: Syntheses, Crystal Structures and Characterization of Two Coordination Polymers Based on Mixed Ligands
WANGYu-Fang(王玉芳) HE Chao-Jun(何朝军)

Compound 1 displays a two-dimensional plane structure consisting of $\mathrm { [ C d _ { 3 } ( b c ) _ { 2 } ( H L ) ] }$ subunits. Compound 2 possesses aone-dimensional chain structure and is further extended into a 3-D supramolecular architecture via hydrogen bonds.Photoluminescence studies showed compound 1 exhibits luminescent emissions with emission maxima at $3 7 5 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ .In compound 2, the weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ atoms are bridged by hydrogen-bonding. The hydrogen interactions provide an effective pathway for the magnetic exchange interaction between $\mathbf { M n } ( \mathrm { I I } )$ atoms.
